default.title: Test demo
default.longText:
How to add a “Blog Page”? {#addBP}

In the left navigation menu of Strapi “Content Manager”, under “Collection types”, search for “Blogs”. On click, you will be navigated to the “Blogs Listing” as shown below:

Image1

Finally, content infrastructure promotes reusability, which is crucial for making the most of content production resources.

Headless CMS vs Traditional CMS: A Comparative Analysis {#differenceCMS}

FactorsTraditional CMSHeadless CMS
ArchitectureOne-to-oneOne-to-many
ExtensibilityMonolithicModular
ResponsivenessLimitedResponsive by design
Implementation and integrationPunctuatedContinuous
EngineeringDIYManaged
ExperienceLegacyModern
SpeedIncreased load durationReduced load times
IterationsLong iterationsRapid development

Basic Blog page Detail {#basicBP}

Click on “Create new entry” button on the top right corner, to add a Blog Page. A “Create an entry” form with basic fields will appear as shown below:

Image2

  1. Title: Enter title of your blog

  2. Created Date: Select the date on which the “Blog” was actually created.

  3. Published Date: The date on which your blog is (will be) published. This field is useful to track the initial/actual published date when a blog is re-published multiple times.

  4. Featured: “On” this toggle, to mark your blog as “featured”.

  5. Long Text: Enter your blog content here and format it as you want.

  6. Image: If your blog has any image, upload it here.

  7. NavURL: In your blog navigates to any other URL, specify it here.

Important Note: Note that NavURL of your blogs should be same as the slug of your blog page.

  1. Vue Reference Code: Mention your vue reference code here.

  2. Classification: Select, appropriate item from the dropdown, to classify your blog.

Image3

Add Blog Classification {#addBPC}

You can add Category in the dropdown list,

From Content Manager >> Collection Type >> Classifications

Image4

Enter details, Save and Publish.

  1. Category (0): Select appropriate Category from the dropdown, to specify to which category your blog belongs.

Add Blog Categories {#addBC}

You can add Category in the dropdown list,

From Content Manager >> Collection Type >> Blog Categories

Image5

Enter details, Save and Publish.

  1. Blog Tags (0): Select appropriate Tag from the dropdown, to specify to which tag your blog belongs.

Add Blog Tags {#addBPT}

You can add Tag in the dropdown list,

From Content Manager >> Collection Type >> Blog Tags

Image6

  1. Blog Author: Select appropriate Author from the dropdown, to specify to which Author your blog belongs.

Add Blog Authors {#addBA}

You can add Author in the dropdown list,

From Content Manager >> Collection Type >> Blog Authors

Image7

Enter details, Save and Publish

  1. Related Blogs (0): Here, all the published non-featured blogs will be listed. If your blog is related to any other blog, select that particular blog here.

  2. Related Featured Blogs (0): Here, all the published featured blogs will be listed. If your blog is related to any other featured blog, select that particular blog here.

  3. Configure the view: Click here, to change the blog’s configuration view

Important Note: Changing the core configuration is not encouraged by us.
  1. Edit the model: Click here, to change the blog’s field.
Important Note: Changing the core configuration is not encouraged by us.

  1. Save: Click to save your blog.

  2. Publish: Click to publish your blog on your website/front-end.

  3. Last Update: This field will show when was your blog last updated.

  4. By: This field shows who last updated the blog.

  5. Editing draft version: This field indicates whether you are editing a draft or a published version of blog.

  6. Title: Enter title of your blog

  7. Created Date: Select the date on which the “Blog” was actually created.

  8. Published Date: The date on which your blog is (will be) published. This field is useful to track the initial/actual published date when a blog is re-published multiple times.

  9. Featured: “On” this toggle, to mark your blog as “featured”.

  10. Long Text: Enter your blog content here and format it as you want.

  11. Image: If your blog has any image, upload it here.

  12. NavURL: In your blog navigates to any other URL, specify it here.

Important Note: Note that NavURL of your blogs should be same as the slug of your blog page.

First, select the content that you want to format, and then click on the required tool.

a. Add a title: Specify the title heading style – H1, H2, etc.

Image10

b. B: It’s a font style tool, to Bond your content.

c. I: It’s a font style tool, to Italic your content.

d. U: It’s a font style tool, to underline your content.

e. T: It’s a strikethrough tool, to strike your content.

  • Example: Strikethrough

f. To box bullet your content

g. To number bullet your content

h. <>: To show “technical code” in your content. This is generally used for the technical documentation website.

i. To insert images.

j. To add hyperlink in your content.

k. To give “quoted” effect to your content, as shown below:

Image11

l. Initially this button will read – “Switch to Preview”, in this mode you can enter content and format. Once you are ready with content, click on this button. It will show a preview of your content and the button will turn to – “Switch to markdown”. “Markdown” is the editable mode.

m. Option to expand your text area.

n. Click on this button to go back to editable mode from the preview mode.

  1. CTA: If there is any Call-to-action button, on your slider, add its title here. Even for this element, you will have the option to format your content as mentioned earlier in “Long Text”.

  2. Icon: If you want to set any icon on your slider, upload the particular icon file here from your system or simply drag & drop.

  3. Hover Icon: If the initial icon you uploaded changes to another icon on mouse hover, upload the new icon to which the original icon changes here.

  4. Editing draft version: This field will indicate the user, whether they are editing a draft version or a published version of the particular page.

    • I.e. If you are editing a draft page, which is not yet published it will show “Edit draft version”.

    • If you are editing a page that is already published, it will show “Editing publish version”.
